Firesetting Milestones Study 2024 : Adrian Seeley (contact@adrianseeley.com)

This anonymous self-report study explores the correlations between firesetting milestones in a convenience sample of 240 volunteers recruited from SurveyCircle between Q3-Q4 2024. The Google Forms based questionnaire captured 52 yes/no questions corresponding to whether or not they have experienced a given milestone. No identifying information such as age, sex/gender, email, or geographic location was collected to reduce self-incrimination bias. No datapoints were removed or modified in any way. Questions were presented in a randomized order to each participant. The prevalence of each milestone as well as contingency tables between milestones pairs have been calculated and presented below. The complete source code for calculations, as well as the raw CSV corpus are both included at the bottom of this text file. This study is not peer reviewed nor published beyond this webpage (from adrianseeley.com). The author paid $73.12 CAD out of pocket to SurveyCircle for the recruitment of participants. The author has no conflicts of interest to disclose, and is not at the time of writing a licensed psychologist or psychiatrist.

Firesetting is a complex behaviour, and the little research that does exist on the topic is typically interested specifically in dangerous or criminal firesetting behaviours. This study takes an exploratory position on firesetting as a whole in order to better understand the co-occurence of different firesetting milestones in a non-clinical population. The results of this study are not intended to be used for diagnostic purposes, but rather to inform future research on the topic. This study and it's data can be cited by referencing:

(2024) Adrian Seeley, Firesetting Milestones Study 2024, adrianseeley.com/fire2024.html.


Prevalence

86.25% (n=207) Cooked with fire
67.08% (n=161) Played with a lighter
65.42% (n=157) Used a charcoal BBQ
64.58% (n=155) Played with matches
62.92% (n=151) Worked in a kitchen
56.67% (n=136) Started a camp fire
54.17% (n=130) Received fire safety training
52.92% (n=127) Lit fireworks
52.08% (n=125) Used a gas BBQ
48.33% (n=116) Started a small fire
42.92% (n=103) Burned leaves and/or brush
41.67% (n=100) Seen a house, apartment, or building on fire
39.17% (n=94) Used an accelerant such as gasoline or lighter fluid to start a fire
38.33% (n=92) Started a fire with friends
37.50% (n=90) Started a fire intentionally
35.83% (n=86) Tried to start a fire with a magnifying glass
32.92% (n=79) Smoked marijuana (weed) or other drugs
32.50% (n=78) Seen a fire get out of control
32.08% (n=77) Smoked cigarettes
31.67% (n=76) Started a fire alone
31.67% (n=76) Started an average size fire
29.58% (n=71) Hurt myself with fire
27.08% (n=65) Burned garbage
26.25% (n=63) Owned a Zippo brand lighter
25.83% (n=62) Smoked while under the legal age
25.42% (n=61) Had to evacuate because of a fire
22.08% (n=53) Used a fire torch
19.17% (n=46) Started a fire accidently
19.17% (n=46) Burned items on a BBQ that weren't food
18.33% (n=44) Used fire as part of a ritual or practice
17.92% (n=43) Worked with Fire
15.83% (n=38) Used fire to burn my own belongings
15.42% (n=37) Thrown or placed dangerous items into a fire
10.83% (n=26) Accidently started a fire in the house
10.42% (n=25) Had a fire get out of control
10.00% (n=24) Attempted to conceal a fire
10.00% (n=24) Started a large fire
9.58% (n=23) Tried to hide a fire that I started
8.33% (n=20) Burned toys or stuffed animals/toys
6.67% (n=16) Been in trouble because of fire
5.83% (n=14) Worked as a welder
5.42% (n=13) Started an extremely large fire
5.00% (n=12) Used fire to burn someone else's belongings
5.00% (n=12) Lied about a fire I started
4.58% (n=11) Hurt someone else with fire
4.17% (n=10) Used fire as a cry for help
3.33% (n=8) Used fire to destroy or conceal evidence of a crime
2.92% (n=7) Been in legal or criminal trouble because of a fire
2.92% (n=7) Used fire to get attention
2.50% (n=6) Used fire to manipulate or control someone
2.50% (n=6) Used fire as a weapon
2.08% (n=5) Set a fire to get revenge


Contingency Tables

Where A = (Cooked with fire), and Where B = (Cooked with fire):
A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 0.00%
A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 100.00%
P(B1:A1) - P(B1:A0) = 100.00%
┏━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃           ┃   A = 0   ┃   A = 1   ┃           ┃
┣━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━┫
┃   B = 0   ┃      33   ┃       0   ┃      33   ┃
┣━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━┫
┃   B = 1   ┃       0   ┃     207   ┃     207   ┃
┣━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━┫

Where A = (Cooked with fire), and Where B = (Played with a lighter):
A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 33.33%
A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 72.46%
P(B1:A1) - P(B1:A0) = 39.13%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 1.92%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 0.00%
A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 100.00%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 10.00%
A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 12.00%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 5.33%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 6.13%

A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 45.90%
P(B1:A1) - P(B1:A0) = 10.15%

A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 100.00%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 4.67%
A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 23.08%

A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 50.00%
P(B1:A1) - P(B1:A0) = 9.09%

A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = 41.67%
P(B1:A1) - P(B1:A0) = 33.33%

A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = 34.91%

Source Code

const fs = require('fs');

function parseCSV(infileName) {
    const infile = fs.readFileSync(infileName, 'utf8');
    const lines = infile.split('\n');

    // read headers
    const headers = lines[0].split('","');
    headers.splice(0, 1);
    for (let i = 0; i < headers.length; i++) {
        headers[i] = headers[i].split('[')[1].split('.]')[0];
    }

    // read rows, convert (yes, no) to (1, 0) respectively
    const rows = [];
    for (let i = 1; i < lines.length; i++) {
        const row = lines[i].split(',');
        if (row.length < 2) {
            continue;
        }
        row.splice(0, 1);
        for (let j = 0; j < row.length; j++) {
            row[j] = row[j] === '"YES"' ? 1 : 0;
        }
        rows.push(row);
    }

    // count each columns frequency
    const frequencyCounts = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < headers.length; i++) {
        let count = 0;
        for (let j = 0; j < rows.length; j++) {
            count += rows[j][i];
        }
        frequencyCounts.push(count);
    }

    // determine column order by frequency
    const frequencyOrder = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < headers.length; i++) {
        frequencyOrder.push({
            index: i,
            count: frequencyCounts[i]
        });
    }

    // sort by frequency high to low
    frequencyOrder.sort((a, b) => b.count - a.count);

    // sort headers by frequency
    const sortedHeaders = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < frequencyOrder.length; i++) {
        sortedHeaders.push(headers[frequencyOrder[i].index]);
    }

    // sort columns in rows by frequency
    const sortedRows = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < rows.length; i++) {
        const row = [];
        for (let j = 0; j < frequencyOrder.length; j++) {
            row.push(rows[i][frequencyOrder[j].index]);
        }
        sortedRows.push(row);
    }

    // return frequency ordered column headers and rows
    return {
        headers: sortedHeaders,
        rows: sortedRows
    };
};

function calculateFrequency(rows) {
    const frequency = [];
    for (let columnIndex = 0; columnIndex < rows[0].length; columnIndex++) {
        let count = 0;
        for (let rowIndex = 0; rowIndex < rows.length; rowIndex++) {
            count += rows[rowIndex][columnIndex];
        }
        frequency.push(count);
    }
    return frequency;
};

function calculateContingency(rows) {
    const contingency = [];
    for (let a = 0; a < rows[0].length; a++) {
        let contingencyRow = [];
        for (let b = 0; b < rows[0].length; b++) {
            let a0 = 0;
            let a1 = 0;
            let b0 = 0;
            let b1 = 0;
            let a0b0 = 0;
            let a0b1 = 0;
            let a1b0 = 0;
            let a1b1 = 0;
            for (let i = 0; i < rows.length; i++) {
                const aVal = rows[i][a];
                const bVal = rows[i][b];
                if (aVal === 0) {
                    a0++;
                    if (bVal === 0) {
                        b0++;
                        a0b0++;
                    } else {
                        b1++;
                        a0b1++;
                    }
                } else {
                    a1++;
                    if (bVal === 0) {
                        b0++;
                        a1b0++;
                    } else {
                        b1++;
                        a1b1++;
                    }
                }
            }
            const contingencyCell = {
                a0,
                a1,
                b0,
                b1,
                a0b0,
                a0b1,
                a1b0,
                a1b1,
            };
            contingencyRow.push(contingencyCell);
        }
        contingency.push(contingencyRow);
    }
    return contingency;
};

function pad(num) {
    return num.toString().padStart(5);
};

function percent(num) {
    return (num * 100).toFixed(2) + '%';
};

const n = 240;
const infileName = `./FT-${n}.csv`;
const { headers, rows } = parseCSV(infileName);
const frequency = calculateFrequency(rows)
const contingency = calculateContingency(rows);
const out = [];

out.push(`Firesetting Milestones Study 2024 : Adrian Seeley (contact@adrianseeley.com)

This anonymous self-report study explores the correlations between firesetting milestones in a convenience sample of ${n} volunteers recruited from SurveyCircle between Q3-Q4 2024. The Google Forms based questionnaire captured 52 yes/no questions corresponding to whether or not they have experienced a given milestone. No identifying information such as age, sex/gender, email, or geographic location was collected to reduce self-incrimination bias. No datapoints were removed or modified in any way. Questions were presented in a randomized order to each participant. The prevalence of each milestone as well as contingency tables between milestones pairs have been calculated and presented below. The complete source code for calculations, as well as the raw CSV corpus are both included at the bottom of this text file. This study is not peer reviewed nor published beyond this webpage (from adrianseeley.com). The author paid $73.12 CAD out of pocket to SurveyCircle for the recruitment of participants. The author has no conflicts of interest to disclose, and is not at the time of writing a licensed psychologist or psychiatrist.

Firesetting is a complex behaviour, and the little research that does exist on the topic is typically interested specifically in dangerous or criminal firesetting behaviours. This study takes an exploratory position on firesetting as a whole in order to better understand the co-occurence of different firesetting milestones in a non-clinical population. The results of this study are not intended to be used for diagnostic purposes, but rather to inform future research on the topic. This study and it's data can be cited by referencing:

(2024) Adrian Seeley, Firesetting Milestones Study 2024, adrianseeley.com.\n\n`);

out.push(`\nPrevalence\n\n`);

for (let i = 0; i < headers.length; i++) {
    out.push(`${percent(frequency[i] / n)} (n=${frequency[i]}) ${headers[i]}\n`);
}

out.push('\n\nContingency Tables\n\n');

for (let a = 0; a < headers.length; a++) {
    for (let b = 0; b < headers.length; b++) {
        const cell = contingency[a][b];
        out.push(`Where A = (${headers[a]}), and Where B = (${headers[b]}):\n`);
        out.push(`A0B1 / A0 = P(B1:A0) = ${percent(cell.a0b1 / cell.a0)}\n`);
        out.push(`A1B1 / A1 = P(B1:A1) = ${percent(cell.a1b1 / cell.a1)}\n`);
        out.push(`P(B1:A1) - P(B1:A0) = ${percent((cell.a1b1 / cell.a1) - (cell.a0b1 / cell.a0))}\n`);
        out.push(`┏━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┓\n`);
        out.push(`┃           ┃   A = 0   ┃   A = 1   ┃           ┃\n`);
        out.push(`┣━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━┫\n`);
        out.push(`┃   B = 0   ┃   ${pad(cell.a0b0)}   ┃   ${pad(cell.a1b0)}   ┃   ${pad(cell.b0)}   ┃\n`);
        out.push(`┣━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━┫\n`);
        out.push(`┃   B = 1   ┃   ${pad(cell.a0b1)}   ┃   ${pad(cell.a1b1)}   ┃   ${pad(cell.b1)}   ┃\n`);
        out.push(`┣━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━╋━━━━━━━━━━━┫\n`);
        out.push(`┃           ┃   ${pad(cell.a0)}   ┃   ${pad(cell.a1)}   ┃           ┃\n`);
        out.push(`┗━━━━━━━━━━━┻━━━━━━━━━━━┻━━━━━━━━━━━┻━━━━━━━━━━━┛\n`);
        out.push('\n');
    }
}

out.push(`\nCorpus CSV\n\n`);
out.push(fs.readFileSync(infileName, 'utf8'));
out.push(`\n\nSource Code\n\n`);
out.push(fs.readFileSync('./fire.js', 'utf8'));

fs.writeFileSync(`FT-${n}-FINDINGS.txt`, out.join(''), 'utf8');
